review:
Lords of Magic: SE

Wobei man +durchgespielt+ wohl nie wirklich sagen kann bei dieser Art von Spiel^^
LOM ist ein Strategiespiel das einen rundenbasiert seine Truppen über die Karte ziehen lässt, Gebäude verbessert, Truppen rekrutiert und dann in Echtzeitkämpfen (mit Pause Funktion) gegen Monster /Einheiten anderer Fraktionen kämpfen lässt.
Die Heldeneinheiten können Artefakte und Heil/Manatränke benutzen, jedoch sind nur 2 Stk. ausrüstbar. Und natürlich können Heldeneinheiten (3 pro Armee) und kleinere Einheiten (bestehend aus 1-3, je nach Art) auch im Level aufsteigen, außer es handelt sich um legendäre Kreaturen oder Spezialmonster z.B. aus dem großen Tempel wie den Zyklopen bei der Erdefraktion, jene haben bereits ihr maximal Level, sind dafür aber stärker als normale Truppen. Und die legendären Kreaturen sind die stärksten im Spiel, wobei es da auch sehr große Unterschiede in der Stärke gibt. Mein legendärer Erdwurm ist z.B. sehr gut, aber die legendären Drachen der Luft+ Feuerfraktion sind soweit ich mich erinnere noch stärker und können sogar Stufe 8-10 Dungeon quasi allein bezwingen.

Zu meinem Durchgang:
Ich hatte mit meiner Lieblingsfraktion: Erde begonnen.
Hab mir wie damals immer üblich noch 2-3 andere Fraktionen +einverleibt+ in dem ich ihre großen Tempel eroberte. Bei Neutralen oder befreundeten Fraktionen kriegt man mehr Truppen. Die Lebensfraktion musste ich erst bestechen, damit sie mich nicht mehr hasste. Dann ging das auch;)

Hatte dann außer meiner Hauptarmee die aus meinem Zwergen-Erdkriegerlord, paar Zwergenaxtwerfern und Zwergnahkämpfern bestand dann mit den besten Bogenschützen und einem Magier aus der Lebensfraktion verstärkt und später mit meinem legendären Erderiesenwurm und 1 Felsschleuderer ergänzt.
Meine Erdhauptstadt verteidigten dann div. Erdetruppen+1 Dieb +1 Krieger und 1 Magier (reine Erdtruppen).

In meiner Ordnungshauptstadt hatte ich durch die Eroberung des großen Tempels noch den Ordnungsmagierlord und 1 hochstufigen Paladin und später einen Dieb. Plus einige Nahkampf+Fernkampfeinheiten. Diese Armee zog dann in der näheren Umgebung umher und lvlte so langsam auf und verteidige die Ordnungsstadt gegen marodierende Truppen (die keiner Fraktion angehörten).

In meiner Lebens- und Wasserhauptstadt (bekam die Wasserfraktion umsonst, weil die Lebensfraktion jene vorher schon übernommen hatte) baute ich ebenso jeweils 1 Schutzarmee auf.

Das ganze fraß dann sehr viel Zeit und Mühe.
Ich war gerade dabei mit meiner Hauptarmee div. Stufe 8-9 Dungeons zu erobern, als plötzlich die Todesfraktion meine Ordnungsarmee und meine inzwischen gegründete 2. Ordnungsarmee überfiel +leider auch vernichtete :(

Allerdings war der Todeslord ziemlich dämlich^^ denn er verlor dadurch ca. 85% seiner besten Einheiten und er floh dann allein vor meiner Hauptarmee.

Zu dem Zeitpunkt gab es außer meiner Fraktion nur noch die Luft, Feuer und Todesfraktionen.
Ich hab dann meine Erdarmee per Teleportationsgebäude (gibts nur bei der Erdefraktion) zu meinem großen Lebenstempel teleportiert und hab einen Angriff auf die Feuerfraktion von Norden aus geführt, während meine Hauptarmee den Todeslord verfolgte.
Ich dachte er sei einigermaßen intelligent+ würde sich in sein Gebiet zurückziehen und noch jede Menge starker Truppen rekrutieren, daher schickte ich meine Hauptarmee in das Todesgebiet.

Während meine Erdarmee ein Dorf der Feuerfraktion einnahm, dort eine Lebensdiebesgilde baute (man hat immer pro Dorf die Wahl zw. Gebäuden der angrenzenden Fraktionen, aber kann nur 1 Gebäude und 1 Wachturm bauen= man sieht sehr viel des Umlandes) und Söldner anheuerte +damit die Feuerfraktion angriff. Später schickte ich dann meine Erdarmee hinter dem Todeslord her, den ich zufällig gesehen hatte.
Meine Hauptarmee vernichtete inzwischen sämtliche Gebäude der Todesfraktion, aber das war nicht mehr nötig denn:
Meine Erdarmee hatte den Todeslord der immer noch fast solo war im Feuergebiet entdeckt und hat mit ihm den Boden aufgewischt.

So endete dann dieser Durchlauf x)

Fazit:
Immer noch ein recht gutes Strategiespiel, mit einigen Schwächen in der K.I und auch manchen Balancingproblemen. Hatte ca. 2 DC's während der gesamten Spieldauer von ca. 7,5 Stunden.

Trotz der sehr angestaubten Grafik+ den Mängeln, vergebe ich u.a. aus Nostalgiegründen immernoch 6/10 Sternchen ;)
Es soll wohl auch eine Art-FanMod geben die vieles am Balancing ändert, aber ich wollte es quasi nochmal im Urzustand spielen so wie ich es damals kannte.

review:
my playtime on steam is totally off: ive easily put 100+ hours into this game 

Lords of magic is a classic

its a game that I played alot as a kid and finally managed to win (kill balkoth) as an adult after I fully grasped the mechanics.

as much as I love lords of magic and I highly recommend it for anyone that's interested it does appear to me to be an unfinished game.

there  are a lot of basic quality of life features missing from the game. For example in the mid-endgame its essential that you start garrisoning troops at your towns and buildings so that trash mobs and low level enemy heroes don't constantly take them over. Its important to do this because your armies cannot move very far and the various elements of your town that produce units are spread away from your city. 

in heroes of might and magic its all in your city so you only have to manage defence for  one thing. Even if you take on multiple cities, you will just have one structure to dump your defensive units in.

in lords of magic you have to generate a lot of trash heroes just to defend your (especially in the later game) many cities and unit producing buildings. Levelling these heroes is really slow and even in the later game they wont be able to manage high level dungeons where they could potentially earn some real experience.

so what you are left with is your main high level party burning through the enemy and then trash left behind to defend that will never really reach a high level. 

another solution is just to pump high level units and watch the enemy throw trash mobs at them forever and ever.

once you know how to significantly outpace the enemy AI for resources (grab as many cities as you can and pump them to high level for max resource gain) the game becomes less about how effective your heroes are and more about access to the end tier units.

in my playthroughs im only ever able to bring one or maybe two heroes close to high level before trashing balkoth because to grind them further would just get boring. Ive already hit the enemy so hard all they can do is generate trash heroes and low level units.

this could be solved by allowing higher level cities to create heroes that start past level 1. 
the way unit production works is that the corresponding basic hero types can hire units and give them bonus experience based on their own level. 

This keeps the trash units useful so long as they are being made by a high level hero. 

the problem is that the heroes themselves unless they are supported by a full mass of trash or by high level units are quite squishy. Its often very annoying to train up low level heroes in the later game.

you have these "marauding parties" that like the other nations will travel around trying to trash your cities and towns. The problem is that they are always trash level and barely any experience. This game really needed more multi level dungeons (and some kind of healing bonus between levels) to make levelling the heroes more fun. As it stands you have  a dozen dungeons or so per nation which 2 or 3 of them being level 10 which means you cant pull them off unless via a high level hero AND high level units. I have even lost legendary units throwing them at these dungeons just to see if they could take them...

this all kind of contributes to the basic flow of the game breaking more and more the farther into the turns you get. 

The other significant issue with lords of magic is the actual real time with pause combat.

this game has a very janky real time system and its obvious that its really a turn based rule set being applied simultaneously for each side.  I think this game would play a lot better as a turn based game. Often a ton of damage will come of units in later game fights and it wont be obvious because the frames of animation per unit are so low. regardless of the gamespeed this is tough to manage. In most RTS games you have quite a high amount of animation frames because its essential for micro, the general idea in lords of magic is that everything is kind of slow so your higher level hero can be easily mobbed and murdered. This makes the most viable combat strategy for almost everything to be tanking units with the highest attack and defend stats in "parry" (defend on yourself to convert half attack value to defence value) while you have some ranged unit or something nasty like a dragon nail everything. 

Magic is great but it takes forever to level up your wizards and you also have to leave them in the mage towers to study spells. This makes their level up path a matter of giving them a few guardian units and just letting the AI try and kill the mage tower over and over.

im really not sure what the developer intended as the end game turn cycle....I take over 70% of the cities by turn 170-ish and I can get multiple legendary by turn 200 which makes the final confrontation trivial. 

I often found myself just using the auto-battle feature on large armies of trash because the micro of so many units with such low frames of animation is less effective than just banging their stats against the enemy in the auto result.

if you have a big high level trash army its almost guaranteed you wont lose any units doing this unless you are up against high tier units. 

I cant help but feel that alot of these features were meant to differentiate Lords from Might and Magic. Its just that ironically the game would play better if the battles were structured closer to might and magic.... considering how important each and every units low frame attacks and defence are. 

Impressions games also made Lords of the realm 1-3 and lords 2 was released just before lords of magic. That game has a much more effective real time battle system that is more typical of RTS games. Its surprising that lords of magic's real time combat seems like such a step backwards. 

other small things irk me like the AI being so easy to beat once you understand how it works.
It will rarely use magic and its very easy to stop them from getting high tier units by greifing the building that makes them or attacking them economically.

On the upside: lords of magic managed to create a generic fantasy setting that somehow feels completely unique and far superior to the might and magic games. Because each nation is tied to some elemental thing the units are quite unique and  the world has a slight alien quality (think cuter morrowind) the art and music are amazing.

its sad that Lords of magic didn't take off like might and magic but its kind of obvious why: its "finished" but its not polished to a high sheen and the choice to pair low frames per action character animation (like a turn based game) in a real time battle engine was a terrible idea.

I think lords of magic was just so ambitious in its scope there's a reason pretty much nothing has followed in its footsteps. Sure there are a million heroes of might and magic clones.....but none I can think of tried to stuff real time into what is clearly a turn based game under the hood.

Ну так...
Неоднозначная ситуация получается. С игрой категорически рекомендую ознакомиться, особенно, тем олдскульным игрокам, которые в своё время, её по каким-то причинам упустили. Игра определённо самобытная и интересная, и вот тут начинается НО... как же чертовски она состарилась, за эти 25 лет, которые я с ней не виделся... :(
После первого получаса игры, олдскулы свело, на глазах проступили слёзы и картинка (на глобальной карте стала как в отрочестве), чарующая музыка, ландшафты, великолепно... но стоит зайти в бой... место слёз занимала кровь, а в голове крутилась одна мысль: "Кто это всё бл№;% понаделал...". Какие здесь убогие анимации, насколько глупо перемещаются войска, да и в целом, какое управление... ПРОСТО ЖУТЬ!  Больше половины боёв кампании, были пройдены кнопкой 'Autocalc'. Порадовало конечно, что в далёком 1997 году, разработчики смогли в дипломатию (передаю пламенный привет серии TotalWar). 
P.S. Кампанию за Порядок я всё-же осилил, Бэлкофа завалил самостоятельно. Больше заставить себя играть в неё не могу, но в глубине души, буду надеяться, что когда-нибудь, запилят ремастер, или может быть даже вторую часть ;)
P.P.S. В бытность, играл в ванильную игру, сейчас хотел именно SE посмотреть и к великому сожалению, рабочего русификатора так и не нашёл (оригинальная игра, помнится была очень хорошо локализована)

review:
"Lords of Magic: Special Edition" is an ancient game from 1997.  It's a whopping 26 years old at the time of this review.  The game lacks support for any modern gaming display resolutions (or widescreen monitors), hasn't been modernised or updated to run smoothly on modern gaming PCs.  Despite this lack of modernisation, it carries a pretty high price tag for such an ancient game.  This seems to have been put on Steam as a nostalgia gouge.

Topically this is basically a clone of Heroes of Might and Magic, but it lacks some of the simplistic charm.  The sheer age of the game and derivative theme make it unrecommendable today. 

"Lords of Magic: Special Edition" is relatively expensive for an abandonware nostalgia gouge, at $5 USD, and it's not worth it.  The game is just too old, hasn't been modernised.  And as the old saying goes, you can't go home again.

review:
Lors of Magic has a unique game concept. In the turn based strategy game you can play many different factions with different units and playstyles, and magic spells. The aim is to get rid of all enemies, especially your elements opposing faction and become the lord of the magic world. The faction of life for example is hostile to death, order against chaos, fire against water, earth against air. 

You can win by amazing tactical combar, outplaying opponents (but it is hard) or by economical aspects, like upgrading your city and getting more resources. If you upgrade everything you will get access to a unique and powerful creature that you can summon in the temple. So the game offers a good variety in options how you may approach to win the game. 

Your main goals therefore are liberating your temple and city and mines and breweries for resource income. If you liberate a different factions temple, they may swear loyality to you and you get a second lord - which is nice if your main lord dies, which means, game over. That said, only one Lord will survive - hopefully you.

I am a huge fan of the game since it came out - which is long in the past. But the game presents some wanted and some unintended difficulties. 
You never know what happens around you, thrilling right? Additionally you definetly need the save function as you likely will test your parties limits, especially when you are new to the game. And this aspect is related to the next aspect, which is the outdated and rather horrible unit control and pathfinding. Some little annoyance is that even though pc's nowadays can calculate everyting in a second, the turn calculation takes a lot of time. Well the field of players will thin out, so it will get batter ;)

All in all i still like this game and but i can only recommend it to people that are searching for interesting game designs or retro gamer. This one has a nice game concept and variety but to be honest, it does need an overhaul to be acceptable by todays standards. Especially the unit control in battle makes life harder then necessary.

review:
Zauberstab eingepackt und los

Hier geht's zu meinem Nostalgie-Waetsch's Play:
https://youtu.be/0jJ7GhI2uhQ

Ganz ähnlich wie beim berühmten Heroes of Might and Magic ziehen wir hier mit Helden los und bauen Stück für Stück unser Reich auf. Zu Beginn wählen wir unsere grundsätzliche Ausrichtung (Kämpfer, Magier, Dieb) und unseren "Magiepfad" (Leben, Chaos, Wasser, Feuer, etc.) und schon geht es los. Wir starten mit einer kleinen Truppe und befreien erst mal den Magieturm, damit wir uns auch Lord nennen dürfen, dann heuern wir weitere Kämpfer an und grasen die Karte nach "Ressourcenspender" wie Goldminen und Brauereien ab. An Ressourcen gibt es drei bzw. vier. Wir haben Gold, Bier, Kristalle und Bevölkerung. Je größer unser Ruhm, umso mehr Leute finden sich in unserem Städtchen ein. Diese können wir dann als Soldaten ausbilden oder zum Goldscheffeln, Bierbrauen oder Kristalle... ja was eigentlich?... abstellen. Die Grafik ist natürlich 1997-like, ziemlich pixelig, die Musik geht gut ins Ohr und die Geräuscheffekte sind passend. Schade, dass man keine Chance hat, die Auflösung von 640x480 Pixel zu verändern. Auch an die Steuerung muss man sich zunächst gewöhnen. Mit Linksklick auswählen und mit Linksklick sagen, wo es hingeht. Rechtsklick ist abwählen. Das ist man heute anders gewohnt. Hat man als die Grafik verkraftet und die Steuerung verinnerlicht, stehen einem viele spaßige Runden bevor. Ach ja, die Kämpfe werden nicht Runde um Runde ausgetragen. Hier spielt man dann in Echtzeit, die man aber jederzeit pausieren kann. Alles in allem ein Spiel, was immer noch Spaß macht und eines Remakes würdig wäre.

Folgt mir auch gerne bei Steam:
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41912197-waetschs-play

author: {'steamid': '76561198012542138', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 627, 'last_played': 1675146892}
review:
[h1] What makes a true classic? [/h1]
Many would say that are the memories that people hold about a particular work of art, others would say that are the remarkable features that it possess, or even the audacity of the developer to try new concepts ahead of their time, stepping on unknown territory that few dared to even look at. This game has all of these elements and more, this game is a work of art, this game is Lords of Magic, a [b]true classic[/b].

It is a game that frequently calls me back to it. I look to play it at least once each year, and it never gets old.

My first contact with this game was on a shareware CD back in 2001, it had the demo of the game along with many others, back then it was one of the few sources of discovering new software. I will never forget the first time i've opened it's menu and listened to the theme and the iconic voice of the narrator. The demo had only the Earth Warrior and the Life Mage to use, and only featured those two civilizations, and you were not able to upgrade any of your buildings too, which prohibits you from acquiring all of the units. Even then, with just that small piece of content, i was able to enjoy many nights of fun, while listening to the legendary arrangements of it's soundtrack. From the small phrases that each unit would say, to every ambient sound, the game created an atmosphere os magic, adventure and mystery. The dark fog of the map was hiding unknown treasures and dangers, it was really a feeling that few games gave me, specially back then. The legendary team of Impressions Games, the same studio that created the legendary Pharaoh title, did a great job. It took me many years to find the full version of it on the internet, because it was never available where i live, and the complete game is a masterpiece.

This game was ahead of it's time in many aspects. Back in 1997 there were very few games that would try emulating a 2.5D real time combat RPG, mixed with a turn based tactical map, fully voiced units, and even a narrator. And Lords of Magic succeeded on it's attempt. Basically you have a board that has units and locations, and you control unit groups that can have a maximum of 3 heroes and 9 other units, using these groups you expand your influence on the map by conquering locations and looting others. Your objective is always to destroy Balkoth the Lord of Death. Unless you are playing Death, then your objective is to exterminate everyone.
The combat in RNG stat based on direct confrontations, but it is a strategy game with a lot of complex mechanics and attributes on each unit. There are Hero units, and they have special abilities that you can use both on the strategic map and in the real time battlefield.
Heroes are separated in three different classes, Mages are fragile on direct combat but have powerful spells from their faith that can harm enemies and help allies. Warriors are extremely strong on direct confrontations of melee combat. Thieves are fragile but have cunning abilities like hiding, increased speed, ranged attacks and can perform many special actions, like knocking out certain enemies, spying on the tactical map and more.
Every nation of this game has special units that are based on their faith, with unique attributes and abilities. Some can fly, some are fast, some are tough, some have magical abilities. Every nation also has a special grand temple which brings many special benefits to the owner and has a legendary creature too that can only be summoned once per game, usually.
Every nation also has a unique soundtrack that fits their theme very well, and is extremely remarkable, combined with their lore that you can find in their buildings and spell books.
In the end, the game looks like a very big board, with each nation having their capital and unit buildings around it, the great temple, and beyond that are the neutral locations that have treasures and enemies. The map never changes, it is all hard coded, but even then, you will find enjoyment playing with different tribes, because it is always different.

Looking through modern lenses, the game has aged very well, it's user interface is very good, compared to other software from it's time and is very elegant in my opinion. The AI is very basic, and can be easily exploited in some particular cases, but event then, sometimes it can surprise you, specially if you don't know how the game works completely. The graphics are charming and the music remains legendary. This Steam version runs very fine and has all the features.

I am sure that i am not the only person that was enchanted by the magic of this game, because there are lot's of fans from all around the world. If you enjoy classic computer games, and also like RTS, map strategy games, this is a must play. The magical land of Urak awaits you!

review:
This game was and still is almost the perfect game. RTS/rpg/Tbs done right for what it was. Most games these days can't even get one genre down, let alone 3. Beware.....!!!!!!!!!!!!!  this game is so good you won't even think about HoM or AoW, Masters of Magic, etc.. This games is the reason why i could never get into any other similar titles, they can't live up to this. 

A few old bugs are still around, mostly involving the map editor- freezes up, move your mouse just can't load up maps you're working on. As far as game play i have not had a single issue.

Don't hit level 2s/4s/6s without sending a scout as Death and Maurader caves/dungeons will likely jack u up and you can feel the unbalance. You can feel the unbalanced units early on and late game bad as certain cavs and archers just live up with the others. I have no idea how i beat this game when i was a kid because as simple as it is there is so much depth here. 

Custom maps offer more challenge if you're feeling froggy and wanna leap- also the map editor just promises the game never really gets stale and will always be fun to come back to. If this game had online and a decent timer/ rank system- I don't think I would ever play other games .

review:
It's charming, that's for damn sure.

I used to play this game with my dad when I was a very little kid, and I was worried that I wouldn't like it when the nostalgia glasses wore off.

Funny thing was, the game was exactly as I remembered. The different factions were varied but consistent. Everything was flavorful. The magic was fun to use. The Chronicles mode was pleasant.

The game's controls are a bit clunky, and you have to do some work to fix how slow some bits of the campaign can be; however, I'd buy this classic a hundred times over. I still wish they made a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999577212', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1643561168}
review:
A super addictive old-school grainy strategy RPG. 

The game is basically Heroes of Might and Magic except a bit more tactical.
When you start a new game you can choose from 3 classes and any of the 8 elements, giving you a lot of freedom of choice for such an old game. Once you have chosen you will appear on the main game map where you can see your town, and caves/place where you will find monsters to defeat, using the ability to summon creatures to aid you, hire more troops that can gain experience with you, research new spells, towns where you can direct townsfolk to work in certain areas to increase your income, this being: (Fame, Gold, Ale, Followers and Crystals). Other heroes will direct your armies as you grow them. From here on you set off to conquer everyone or save the realm.

The combat can be clunky and frustrating, so more than half of the time, you auto-calculate your battles.

The game itself has a dark yet fantasy themed grainy feel to it, reminding me of LoTR and shining in terms of 'classic'.

It is one of my all-time favourites. I still have the original disc. The voices, sound and music add a lot of atmosphere. Perfect for those cozy-fantasy eves while listening to your favourite podcast. 

Also...

Please add achievements ! ! !

author: {'steamid': '76561198054312563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 4600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4600, 'last_played': 1648737054}
review:
Strategico a Turni, ambientazione fantasy 2D.

Ho deciso comunque di fare una recensione anche su questo gioco perché ha delle sue peculiarità per essere uno strategico di 25 anni fa! 

Premettendo che non consiglierei a nessun nuovo giocatore di comprarlo poiché pieno di bug, combattimenti lenti e un po' macchinosi, inaccettabili per gli standard odierni. Questo è un cimelio che appartiene ormai allo scorso millennio, e si deve valutare come tale.

Detto ciò voglio spendere alcune note favorevoli, soprattutto per gli amanti del genere che lo rendono comunque unico:
- Fazioni, esistono 8 fazioni legati agli elementi di questo mondo fantastico, tutti estremamente personalizzati e con le proprie peculiarità. Le fazioni sono vita e morte, fuoco e acqua, aria e terra, ordine e caos.
- Politica, troviamo un inizio di intelligenza artificiale sulle attitudini degli avversari, legati a doni, favori e scambi di vario genere(oggetti, magie, edifici). Le relazioni tra differenti reami all'inizio di una partita sono legate:  1) alla dualità delle singole fazioni, ad esempio caos e ordine sono nemici per natura(come scozzesi e altri scozzesi). 2) In base a come le fazioni son disposte nell'indicatore dei turni in basso a destra dello schermo, più sono vicine al colore della tua fazione più saranno amichevoli con te questo solo al principio, poi le guerre cambiano tutto.
- Magie, ogni fazione ha magie proprie uniche di attacco, difesa e utilità uniche più un set di magie generiche comuni a tutti. Per studiarle funziona in questo modo : Costruito la torre dei maghi, hai a disposizione una biblioteca nella quale puoi mettere a studiare un certo numero di maghi che aumenta con il livello della torre del mago. Ogni magia ha un numero di giorni umani che impiega per essere appresa, il tempo in turni impiegato per imparare una determinata magia sarà: numero di giorni umani/ (somma totale del livello dei maghi che studiano contemporaneamente)  questo numero indica quanti turni ci vogliono per impararla, e una volta imparata sarà una conoscenza indelebile del tuo lord. Altra parte importantissima, andando avanti con la partita e soggiogando regni avversari, potrai costruire e imparare le magie di ogni regno (Una miriade di magie diverse).
- Esercito: l'esercito è diviso battaglioni da massimo 30 unità dove all'interno avremo max 3 campioni e 
 max 27 truppe. I campioni possono essere di 3 classi diverse mago, guerriero o assassino, mentre i soldati si dividono fanteria corpo a corpo, fanteria a distanza o fanteria magica di diversi tipi in base alla fazione con cui si sta giocando, ma in genere ogni fazione ha almeno una 10 di unità diverse da costruire. Parte davvero interessante,  campioni e truppe, hanno un livello che aumenta con le battaglie vinte, il limite delle truppe solitamente e nettamente inferiore a quello dei campioni. I campioni salendo di livello, possono se messi nelle rispettive strutture  (esempio paladino nella struttura delle truppe corpo a corpo) può trasmettere nei turni la propria conoscenza all'edificio permettendo di produrre truppe con esperienza avanzata e quindi più forti. Altra peculiarità, i campioni possono trovare e indossare oggetti trovati nei vari dungeons nella mappa che aumentano le statistiche oppure danno abilità o magie.
- Dungeons ed edifici: La mappa e ricca dungeons ed edifici, che ci permetteranno di ottenere risorse, esperienza e oggetti senza dover incontrare obbligatoriamente in battaglia le altre fazioni. Le ambientazioni e la disposizione delle truppe iniziale possono far cambiare radicalmente il risultato di una battaglia. Alcune battaglie se svolte in modalità "automatica" saranno perse, e occorrerà giocarle manualmente per avere qualche speranza di vincere, limitare le perdite o fuggire da un imboscata.
- Roccaforti: Le roccaforti sono le città principali delle fazioni, da difendere in quanto producono il numero più alto di risorse, permettono di utilizzare e aumentare i livelli delle baracche delle truppe e producono SEGUACI, che è la risorsa che ci permetterà di reclutare le unità in modalità NON MERCENARIA. Quindi è molto importante difenderle. I seguaci si uniranno a te 1 volta alla settimana in base al quanta fama hai accumulata. La fama si fa con le battaglie, liberazione dei grandi templi, dungeon.
- Edifici delle risorse: Alcuni edifici sulla mappa, una volta liberati dai nemici, genereranno giornalmente delle risorse, utili per pagare il mantenimento delle tue truppe.
- Aree di combattimento che cambiano in base al dungeon, edificio o terreno calpestato, altissimo livello di personalizzazione anche se semplice.

Pseudo-Contro:
- Grafica: E' un gioco di 25 anni fa, quindi vintage al massimo poiché non potrebbe competere con una valutazione sulla grafica moderna.
- Intelligenza-Artificiale: Molto scarsa per quanto riguarda il late game e altre dinamiche ingaggio degli attacchi da parte del computer. Ad ogni modo è un precursore di un modello di intelligenza artificiale, molti giochi hanno raggiunto queste dinamiche solo alcuni anni dopo(ovviamente dico precursore ma è un gioco di nicchia, quindi non ci sono molti casi che possono aver preso proprio come esempio questo gioco).

Contro: 
- Movimenti: marciando su alcune parti della mappa la penalità di movimento è altissima, facendoti perdere molti turni, cruciali per vincere.
- Signore della morte troppo aggressivo, in maniera random potresti essere investito dal signore della morte che è nemico di tutti, ed è troppo forte. Lo puoi battere solo con eserciti potenziati al massimo, avrebbero dovuto predisporre un timer prima del suo arrivo, una centinaia di turni sarebbero stati sufficenti così da farti vivere di più i combattimenti tra fazioni pre-avvento del signore della morte.
- Editor delle mappe: complicato, non di facile utilizzo.
- Navi: le imbarcazioni possono portare massimo 1 campioni con 3 gruppi di truppe, per portare 1 battaglione da 30 occorrono minimo 3 navi. Le navi sono unità esercito che possono combattere da sole.
- Bug: il gioco non è ben implementato su tutto, si presenteranno moltissimi bug che non sto ad elencare.
- SALVATAGGIO AUTOMATICO: Non funziona bene, non fidatevi, fate almeno un salvataggio manuale frequentemente.


Il mio resoconto rimane comunque POSITIVO per tutti i nostalgici amanti del genere poiché è davvero unico, per tutti quelli invece che si approcciano a questo gioco per la prima volta, consiglio di armarsi di notevole pazienza e fare SALVATAGGI MANUALI OGNI TURNO.

review: I played this game for countless hours in the 90s when I was a kid, as it was one of the few games I owned at the time. For whatever reason, I thought about the game for the first time in many moons so I decided to buy it on steam to see if my affinity for this (and Lords of the Realm II) stood the test of time or if it was simply nostalgia. To my surprise, I still very much enjoyed playing through the game. It's much easier than I recalled and the games tend to end prematurely due to the mishaps of the AI, but given how dated the game is, I think it holds up reasonably well. Undoubtedly, nostalgia plays a pivotal role in how many games I have completed since, but I still recommend the game to friends given the price. I wouldn't expect one unfamiliar to the franchise to become instantly enthralled, however, it is well worth the purchase in my opinion. It should be noted that I have an affinity for turn-based games and this one blends together real-time combat to give it that extra oomph. Combining pseudo-myth-based creatures/characters and other fantasy tropes makes for a pleasing aesthetic despite the outdated....everything. I love this game and I sincerely wish that someone would make a modern sequel. The world and story has a strong foundation on which to build.

review:
Ha! I used to play this all the time. I liked talking about this game on the LOMSE message board (even with the devs when gaming communities weren't so toxic), way way back in the day. It was Sierra/Impressions (maker of the city-builder, Pharaoh!), as I recall. Sadly, no longer making stuff on their own.

The music is sill pretty dang good, and the game is a neat mix of turn based with real time combat.

It's not balanced or boring that way. It's a game where you can find imbalanced and stupid strategies, like flying unhittable Air thieves (assuming nobody has a bow & arrow to shoot back at you).

The physical manual was great. There was some super lore behind this game.

It was underappreciated in its time, so I'm glad it has another bit of life on Steam.

review:
This is a classic buy and still one of my all time favorite games, here's a huge variety, 8 faiths to choose from with 3 heroes each, all with different strengths and weaknesses, all faiths have maybe 30+ spells each to research and each have unique units. The graphics are still reasonable in my opinion for it's age,  we are talking nearly 25 years old., the map view of the world still looks quite nice when zoomed out to the middle setting. 

Select your hero then go explore the world, a mix of turnbased and real time strategy, form alliances and trade with other faiths and look for legendary items to equip on your lords. The music track for this game is superb, each faith having a music to fit it.

downside yes the AI is not that great, but it also means you can mostly finish the game at your own pace. You can also get mods to change your experience and make it much harder.

review:
Had some good memories of the back in the early 00's, but the steam version is more buggy than I remember. 

Sometimes, when you equip artifacts, there is a bug where they don't properly boost your stats, so you have to reload a saved game, or reboot the game for them to work. Other times there are bugs where you can't equip 2 artifacts at the same time, even if you fit the qualifications for both. I had Fire warrior and trying to equip both Dragon Armor and the Swords of Flames, but sometimes it wouldn't let me equip both and other times it would.

The balance can also be all over the place. A Lvl-1 hamlet might have 3 Lvl-1 centaurs and a mite that you can steam-roll. Then start another new game, go into another Lvl-1 cave and have to face the same thing, BUT with 3 Lvl-3 wolves instead of the Mite.

Also some of the tooltips seem out of wack. Hand of Fate (Chaos spell) said I should have 66% chance to deal damage to a target (I was Lvl 2), but I somehow failed 3 straight times vs. level 1 targets. Odds of that are happening are like 4%, so maybe just unlucky, BUT I had Luckstone (+3 luck) equipped. I guess luck must not do much of anything, but the game never specifies what it is supposed to do.

review: Highly recommended classic strategy game from 1997! Adventuring through a "Tolkien-esque" world (vaguely reminiscent of Middle-Earth from the "Lord of the Rings"), you fight tactical battles in real-time, but manage your kingdom on the turn-based campaign map. In my experience, it seems to work just fine on modern systems, but you might have to turn on the compatibility mode on modern versions of Windows, and there is no wide-screen support (the game window is in the 4:3 aspect ratio), at least without mods. However, the absolute best part of this game has to be the amazing soundtrack - each faction has its own unique, thematic music, and the theme changes as you explore the lands of the other factions on the campaign map. The music is so atmospheric - both melancholic for a lost, dying world and epic for a fantasy adventure at the same time! It is just so good! The game is worth getting and playing just to listen to its wondrous soundtrack!

review:
Un jeu assez dépassé mais qui garde son charme. Il y a une grande diversité d'unités et de surprises. Les factions sont uniques et il est possible d'en jouer plusieurs simultanément en les cooptant: cela vous évitera de jouer six parties différentes pour les tester une par une. Visuellement, ça a assez bien vieilli: on parle bel et bien d'un jeu de 1997-98 ici! Contrairement à plusieurs jeux plus récents, la diplomatie et le commerce peuvent s'avérer un moyen efficace d'améliorer sa position, en admettant qu'on en ait les moyens! Les éléments RPG (items magiques, progression des héros, etc.) sont très bien exploités. Les combats en temps réel ne sont pas extraordinaires mais ils restent plaisants.

Côté négatif, les maraudeurs et bandits donnent souvent plus de fil à retordre que les factions ennemies, et le jeu ne pardonne pas. Il est très difficile de se relever d'une seule grosse défaite. Le jeu compte aussi son lot d'irritants: ennemis impossibles à abattre, déséquilibre dans la puissance des unités, progression assez lente en terme d'xp, distances incroyablement longues à parcourir sur la carte, combats un peu trop courts, etc. Le développement de l'économie est également un peu lent. Globalement, je dirais que certaines mécaniques sont fastidieuses. Cela dit, je ne me suis pas ennuyé une seule minute lorsque j'ai essayé le jeu pour la première fois dans les années 2000, et pas plus lorsque j'y suis revenu 17-19 ans plus tard!

review:
Its an old game and a great one. If you can get past the graphics, you will find a highly challanging strategy game with a surprisingly steep learning curve. Pretty much any fantasy creature you can name is represented in the game somewhere.

You play as one of eight faiths (life, death, air, water, fire, earth, chaos or order). You start with a small group of followers and travel around the map fighting in caves, houses ect, all gaining experience, gold, mana, fame and ale. Find artefacts of great power as you travel. 

Each faith comes with its own unique units and spells. Each has its strengths and weaknesses but each is powerful and can be combined with units of other faiths when you are strong enough. Liberate your great temple for a deadly and unique legendary creature. 

The battles are brilliant when you fight them yourself - this is where the mages really come into their own. 

Thieves patrol the map spying and stealing - they may not look great at the start but they are loads of fun to play. 

A brilliant game, would highly recommend it.

review:
Old school goodness. It has it's problems and oddspots to be certain, but the sheer variety of play styles and options available make it more than worth it.
Pros: Atmosphere- the visuals and sound are fantastic.
Variety- With 3 classes (Warrior, Mage, Thief) and plethora of faiths. You even get to play as the big bad after you beat the game!

Cons-Showing its age- The controls are a bit clunky at times, and not all the information is presented too clearly, though you pick it up pretty fast.
The randomness- Sometimes...it is a little unfair. The Chaos starting area seems especially prone to this. Random dungeons, scattered to help your rookie lord level up, have levels assigned to them. Level 3 elsewhere may have some semi tough baddies it, but  nothing extraordinary.
Level 3 in the Chaos area has the highest summonable monsters in the game. 

So, its uneven, a bit dated, but an absolute BLAST to play!

review:
So, played this again recently for the sake of nostalgia. It's just as bad as I remember.

Unlike it's antecedents, Lords of the Realm and Lords of the Realm 2, this game barely qualifies as a strategy game in any meaningful way. Indeed, it makes me wonder if the developers were even the same group of people.

This game tries really, really hard to be Heroes of Might & Magic with active battles, but it just doesn't work well. Best part of the game is its soundtrack, though it sounds plenty dated. The town and battle UI are both awful, the developer clearly wanted to create something immersive for town, but what it ends up being is an indiscernible mishmash of interface hotspots on a pre-rendered screen that don't behave like you'd anticipate. Same kind of thing in battles, but with a mouse interface that ends up doing things you don't want your units to do.

Active battles are mostly awful. It's nigh impossible to close range on most ranged units and your guys just fall over dead with alarming speed. The garbage auto-calc algorithm just applies 100% of the damage to the units in order, so there's no effective way to spare units, especially early game, other than to not have them in the battle. Healing takes a veritable eternity.

If you're looking for a classic fantasy strategy game along these lines, maybe play Age of Wonders, a game that will stand the test of time for a long time. Or, Battle for Wesnoth if you're looking for something closer to Fire Emblem. If you want a game with active battles (not my thing), I hear most of the Total War games are good enough for them to churn out 834297 sequels, and that's kind of what this attempts to be, similar to LotR 1&2 mentioned above, just with fantasy units and "better' graphics.

review:
This game still holds up.

Name a fantasy race or creature, and there's probably a faction for it. I'm talking about pre-Warcraft III RPG/RTS mechanics. I'm talking about summoning legendary creatures like hydras and dragons. I'm talking about marshalling barbarian hordes, dwarven armadas and undead legions in a granular, supremely rewarding way.

This was an early Sierra game, so it's not the most balanced, graphics and dialogue are kind of cheesy, and it can be slightly janky at times. I wouldn't call this a 4X game, but it's similar...it's like fantasy Civ. If you can deal with the antiquated graphics, this game is dumb fun for hours, comparable to only Medieval Total War or Age of Empires II.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072202781', 'num_games_owned': 306, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1688009896}
review:
This is one of those games back in the 90s, I orignally discovered it as a Demo on another game disc.

I gotta say its old, but still fun. The only problem is that it can be a bit overwhelming and confusing at first, but once you know what to do and get into the main of the game it becomes very fun.

Heres a few tips if you decide to get this, for early game.
-Take any places with greyish flags over them, these are controlled by hostile neutrals, most produce some kind of ECO item.
-Focus on getting at least a small second force once you get some ECO going. (2 units more), a 2nd champion early off is to pricey but can help if you can afford it.
-Once you have the 2nd force, push for your Temple, it is the largest looking building and usally very close to your starting town.
-Once you take the temple, you can then start placing workers (Followers) In your town, this will produce more ECO items.
-Try to make deals with other factions that are in their favor, doing this makes them friendlier towards you and more likely to cut better deals your way. This is a double edge sword as making deals in their favor usally hurts your ECO but you can usally gain some units that you can produce yet (Such as earth being able to get fire soldiers)

From there its mostly trail and error and learning whole to deal with first, who to trust, ETC.

review:
I cut my video game playing teeth on this game. Yeah, new games look nicer but they are really just more complexities and flashing lights. Lords of Magic is a true gem, simple to learn yet hard to master. Even though I have played this game as possibly every type of character, I still like to come back to it.
The variability in each play-through is great, do you like sneaking and theaving? Perfect. Do you like being the noble paladin bringing justice to the lawless? Be it. Do you dream of obliterating an entire army with a single spell? Do it. With 24 unique starting characters featuring three different character types and eight powerful and unique magics you can create your own legends.
I have not seen any game with a magic system quite like this one. The spells do fit into common categories and several spells have similarities to spells from other "Religions" (schools) but the way each team uses its magic is so different it gives real character to the game.
If you want even more out of this game then look up Mantera's mod, adding more spells, improving the AI and giving you even more possible starting setups. (http://mantera.xorgate.com/) Mantera also supplies the tools to do modding yourself.
It may be retro, but it is also refreshing to play!

review:
当我还在上中学时，便遇到了这样一款游戏，造型各异的八个种族，各具特色的三类英雄，操控英雄与部队进行即时对战，当时的我很快便被这款游戏所吸引，在老旧的电脑上凭借自己生涩的英语体验着这魔幻世界。
时光荏苒，一晃已经快二十年过去了，当初那些老旧的游戏，有些依然在陪伴我打发闲暇时光，有些却已经淹没在记忆的长河里，或许是灵光一闪，让我又想起了当初的那个魔幻世界，然而时间已经过去的太久，只记得 magic 和 lord 两个关键字，无论如何也难以在浩如烟海的网络上寻找着相关游戏的资源。
然而在steam的搜索栏上打出这两个词的时候，我却意外地看到了熟悉的名字。
熟悉的画面，熟悉的八个种族，熟悉的三种英雄，尽管画面在今天看来已经过于粗糙，但当我选择秩序族的盗贼英雄进入游戏时，仿佛回到了二十年前的那个下午，尘封的记忆一下被打开，如泉涌般流进了我的脑海。
或许我们在追求的不是那些值得怀念的游戏，而是那些再也回不去的时光。
感谢steam，能让我再次找回那些回忆。

Простая, атмосферная с удивительной озвучкой. К графике привык - ибо играю в нее с момента выхода то есть с 1997 года. Даже ставил музыкальные темы  раньше на свой старенький сотовый телефон. Проходил за всех лордов. Как тут упоминалось в отзывах - легче всего играть за лорда Балкота нежитью. Но, чтобы за него играть надо сначала у него выиграть любым другим лордом. Игра не отличается сложностью. А ужасы текстур отдают чем-то готическим. И играть за лордов Хаоса действительно непросто. И не только в данной  стимовской версии. Я проходил за хаос воином на тигре. Не смог пройти магичкой и воровкой. Просто нейтралы завалили. Легче играть за эльфов - их лучники шотят очень далеко и очень быстро. Добежать до них удается далеко не каждому. В целом  для ознакомления пройти можно.
P.S. Это версия расширенная. Здесь добавлено много артефактов и есть режим игры - компания. Играть намного интереснее.

review:
One of the best PC games of all time. This game was made by the same company that created the Lords of the Realm series, and this game was released after Lords of the Realm II. If you like that style of game and fantasy, you will really enjoy this. Personally, I've logged over a thousand hours into this (I played it for years before Steam added it) and have beaten the game over 100 times.

There are three different lord types (Mage, Warrior, Thief) and eight elemental factions (Life, Fire, Chaos, Air, Death, Water, Order, and Earth), each with their own set of spells, units (for the most part), and play-style.

For those of you who do not judge a game by its graphics, which "celebrity" is streaming it, or how much cinematic content is in the game, you should really give Lords of Magic a try. The soundtrack is wonderful, created by Keith Zizza. He really captured the "sound" of each element. I know that may sound odd, but if you listen to the music, you will understand what I mean.

10/10! Sierra's masterpiece.

Combat: You can pause combat and give orders to each unit, then unpause and let them follow their orders.  You can pause and unpause as often as you like, so you have direct control over combat

Cons:  There is a steep learning curve.  Even though I played this game before, it took a little bit to get the swing of things.  Save often!
Stronghold management can get tedious.  You have to scroll the map to find each one, then go inside each one to set up how you want your followers disrtibuted.

review: Heavily inspired by Lord of the Rings, this is one of the most unique games with beautiful old school graphics. Having great variety with 8 faiths to choose from, each with their own spells(Life, Death, Order, Chaos, Air, Earth, Fire and Water). Many creature types(Elves, Dwarves, Human Chivalrous Knights including Lancelot of the Lake, Barbarian hordes, Fire giants, Air Giants, Faries, Pegasus riders, Fire dragons, and Ice Drakes, Goblins, Orcs, Centaurs, Cyclops, Fire, Air and Water elementals, Lizardfolk, Amazons, Dark Elves). After picking your lord's class(Warrior, Mage, or Thief) you choose their faith whereupon you are placed on the world map of Urak ready to battle hooligans inhabiting local dwellings. After leveling up your small army somewhat, it is time to liberate the Great Temple of your faith and claim the capital as your own where you may direct what your new followers produce(Gold, Ale, Crystals, and Fame). Every 7 days starting on day 7 if you have freed the Great Temple you get more followers which can also be trained at the Barracks, Thieves Guild, or Mage Tower to be new troops for your armies. You may also barter with the other faiths and build relations and if you have neutral or better relations with a faith that has not freed their Great Temple, you can free it and gain their lord and some of their units as yours to control and their lord acts as an heir if your lord dies. It does have clunky controls which are fine once adapted to. Instead of using screen side mouse scrolling, use the arrows on keyboard. Has several great mods such as Ellelone's Zero mod and GS5R3 or the unofficial U302 mod not made by Ellelone with great balancing and refining of gameplay including scroll speed controls. Wonderful game to try at the very least and a great price!

review:
Lol I love this game, it is so damn annoying but for some reason I find it fun.  As a time saver, I recommend making a hero that starts with an item that automatically fully heals you at the end of each battle, otherwise you are going to get bored really fast.  

You start off picking your hero type, thief/mage/warrior.  I recommend all newcomers play a warrior until you figure out what the other two can do.  The only exception I would make is creating an Air Mage with this one staff that lets you start the fight off casting a spell that lets you do a D.O.T. on a large swath of the enemy.  After you pick your type of hero, you will have to choose, Air, Water, Fire, Earth, Order, Chaos, Life.  Death only becomes an option after you beat the game once.  

I would suggest picking a Life Warrior and get purchase the staff that recovers your health after battle.  Then it becomes a matter of getting some valuable backup.  I suggest after freeing up your temple you go rescue Air's temple (to the west) and then immediately going south to free Order's temple.  With Order's temple you can train Order warriors in their barracks, knights are sone of the best units and when you get them to 5 you can change them into holy knights, the only unit like this that goes past level 5.  Once you beat the game, again, you can try Death, and playing as Death is loads of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058231241', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1523208294}
review:
First off I want to say that I love this game, I'm pretty sure it was the first real game (non education game) that I played growing up, back when I was 4 and 5 years old.  The game is great and the nostalgic feeling I get from it is amazing.  It's still difficult and challenging all these years later and it's a lot of fun. 

 That said, I would not recommend this game to other people unless those people played the game originally.  Although the game is fun, unless you have the nostaglic draw to play the game it can be very tedious at times, it has many bugs, such as, the art pictures of characters will start being very pixellated and messed up, that's stage one, after a while, the loading screens will take on that effect as well, stage 3 it can happen to the whole world.  But worst of all is stage 4, which may appear at any point beyond stage 1, where you buttons dissapear.  The only way to fix it is to relaunch the game, but can be upsetting because you literally lose the button to save your game, so you'll have to revert back to your autosave. (which I've done already today since I bought it)

The multiplayer in the game has never worked, and still does not work today, not so bad because steam let us know before I bought it, but it's still a bit of a dissapointment.

I love this game and it's always going to be one of my favorite games, but because of how it is I wouldn't recommend it to new people.  I don't think that the game would be appreciated by the audiance of people who only enjoy the more modern and polished games that are out today.  However if you like the old games with their bugs and all, this is a fantastic game.

Some of the coments talk about how the game is severly unbalanced, and to a point that is true.  But I never felt like it was a detrement, it is simply an aspect of the game, yes some characters are stronger than others in specific situations but every character of every race has it's strong suit.  Life archers have the most range, Earth Axe throwers have the strongest melee of rangers, Air slingers although weak can fly and as such go over terrain that melee characters cannot harm them.  Air and Fire warriors are very easily locked up, if you attack them with a couple people they get caught defending themselves and cannot attack, however to compensate for that they have insane damage if they can hit.  So I just have people in front of them to get hit and then stand in the 2nd row obliterating everyone.  The game isn't exaclty balanced, but because it's not you end up going around the world taking characters from each race that you want in your party to build a group that meets your play style.  And that's part of the fun of the game.  Learning their strengths and utilizing them.  Every race has units that are weak compared to the whole with the exception of death having units I would conisder to be stronger than average across the whole, but that's okay because they are the villians of your game.  And if they weren't stronger than you then what would be the point.

I've rambled on enough, but my point is, I love this game and if you're willing to give it a shot despite it's issues it's certainly a game you can enjoy, but that for the majority of players I wouldn't recommend it as it's just too old and flawed.

P.S.  Pro tip,  if you Ctrl click a character you can grab a single unit of a group of 3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054340291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5045, 'last_played': 1518384659}
review:
I played this game since it came out. Loved the game! It has most things you look for in a strategy game. Stopped playing it when I went to Win 7 because it was not compatible. Now with STEAM I can play again on any OS. Great! 
  I can't believe so many people here autocalc the battles??? that is part of the fun. besides you can do MUCH better fighting them. I stiill autocalc the easy ones, but if I am losing people I back up and fight them and WIN! no losses. only healable damage. I always play on the most difficult setting, and with a few tricks, I beat it every time. 

Here is a few tricks to help win the harder battles without losing your weeker men:
1) keep one out of the three men from you groups likely to die back from the battle. 
2) you can even send them to the "flee the battle" flag. then when it's over you heal them and they're good as new. With experience! 
3) In the beginning, train the troops you want to keep, (leaders, archers, etc. But hire mercs as foot soldiers likely to die. they are cheaper initially. Then you basically sacrifice them in battle. this avoids the expensive upkeep.And gives the keepers the experience. Then once your leaders gain experience put them in the training places so they confer experience to the new recruits. (upgrading helps this) Then you go back and train footmen you want to keep. Do the keep one back thing till they are powerful enough not to die easily.
4) If an army attacks that's just TOO powerful, build an army of all mercs, attack them (NOT auto) then use them to take out most of the power players. They will be destroyed so there is no upkeep. Then attack them with your trained army and crush them for the experience. (you may want to leave the leaders barely alive so your trained keeper army gets the credit for destoying them) Their magic users will have used all of their mana fighting the first group so you won't have to worry about that. 
5) Save before every battle. then when you enter the battle scene make note of where the men are, and where you want them to be. autocalc to get back out. load save. switch your men around so when you re-enter they will be positioned where you want them. this is easier if you name your men. that way if you have multiple archers or whatever, you know which is which.
  Good luck! Have fun!

review:
Do you like adventure? Maybe you like a quick RTS. Grand Strategy? RPG? This classic game ties all of these elements into one and provides you hours of replayability. Choose to be a Warrior, Mage or Thief amongst one of eight realms each with their own strengths and weaknesses. Control resources to upkeep your armies and gain followers from the fame of your victories. 

Collect artifacts to strengthen your heroes and research spells to conquer your foes. Upgrade your characters to ensure victory. Capture your enemies to reveal more about their lands and upgrade your temples for ultimate units. Forge alliances with other realms to crush foes only to betray allies when their back is turned. A formula for success, this game is its own legend. 

tl;dr: 5/7

review:
По сути писать обзоры к таким играм нет никакой надобности и пользы.

Они существуют здесь для того, чтобы дать возможность людям, которые привыкли к ним и полюбили (даже по иррациональным причинам), поиграть не отвлекаясь от удобного сервиса. Все, что им нужно знать - запускается и работает? Да, по крайней мере у меня без проблем.

Для остальных, тех кто не разбежится взглянув на скриншоты - ну вот вам хороший пример того, насколько разными могут быть старые игры и как интересно с ними работает время. Меньшинство стареет хорошо, превращаюсь в классику, эта постарела кошмарно.

Графика, которая была приемлема и как-то даже будоражила воображение, сейчас откровенно уродлива. В "стратегическом" режиме из плохоньких текстур создается безжизненный пейзаж и плохо читаемая карта. В "боевом" видим анимацию характерную скорее для спектрума - кажется будто комп лагает или здесь 8 кадров в секунду. Что, 1997 год? Не оправдание: "Warcraft 2" вышел в 1995 - один короткий взгляд и все сразу понятно.

Механика - один большой анахронизм. Т.е. все максимально долго, неудобно, требует лишних действий и местами неочевидно. Пример: солдаты стоят денег + требуют зарплату (большую); хотите, чтобы юнит просил зарплату меньше, нужны последователи; хотите последователей, тогда зарабатывайте славу в бою и только потом каждый n-ый ход (при наличии замка) получите несколько штук. Оценили длину цепи для найма одного толкового солдата?

Еще пример: хотите исследовать новое заклинание? Сперва сходите в другое здание, наймите там волшебников, отведите в библиотеку и уже там выберите то, что они будут медленно исследовать. Зачем в такой простой вещи этот лишний микроменеджмент? Я не за упрощение всего и вся, но давайте представим, что в какой-нибудь Need for Speed для замены бампера нужно ехать в мастерскую и 5-10 минут стоять в пробке. Это ничего не дает и никак не обогащает.

Все-таки то, что можно сделать проще - делается проще.

Мне нравилась эта игра в детстве, но я ставлю палец вниз. Нет у нее какого-то уникального образа, нет хорошей истории, нет образцовой игровой механики и каких-то толковых идей, которые стоит тащить в настоящее.


Так в итоге, возвращаясь к предисловию и отвечая на вопрос - зачем писал? В попытке, в очередной раз, субъективно разобраться почему что-то становится классикой, а чему неизбежно суждено забыться.

review:
This game deserves to be so much better known than it is! My dad bought it on release with our first computer back in the late 90s and it is still his absolute favorite game now in 2017. I used to spend hours watching him play it, and even now it's still a ton of fun. 

I think what really makes it is the level of detail. The developers clearly spent a lot of time working on the lore. Each of its faiths has a great, distinctive feel. Every unit has their own separate portrait and voice prompt (these get repetitive but really add depth). The combat is really clunky and can be very challenging and seemingly random (I tend to just autocalc everything if I'm being honest), but there's just something so satisfying about building up your awesome army and conquering your neighbors. 

Although it can be kinda easy to get stuck in a gameplay rut, there's a decent amount of variation to be found through the various faiths and lords, the map editor (completely change up the map or even build your own... it adds way more variety than you'd expect), and the story mode expansion. That being said, I really wish this game had gained the popularity needed to get a sequel (or two or three). It would be awesome to see a more modern take on this. One thing I'd really like to see added is more expansion to the economy. A more robust trading system and financial management would really help the endgame (at which point your only options are really to kill off all of your allies, wander around fighting random dungeons, or just quit your hard-earned game. Boo!).

If you like strategy, fantasy, or especially both, this is definitely worth a try.

review:
Good game, but has a few flaws.

My main annoyance is the game is very oriented towards save-reload gaming. Why:
- Death of your character = lose game.
- Enemy units pop out of fog of war and kill you the same turn. Much farther sight range would have been useful.
- Game loves spawning "marauders" (neutral units) that kill you randomly for above reason.
- Loss of any regular unit is very devastating early and mid game, so you end up replaying battles a lot until there are no losses (generous auto-calc also encourages this).
- Early game quest to free Great Temple doesn't permit any mistakes for harder factions.
- Stats are rarely explained by the user interface (e.g. spell effects) and so a trial and error approach is necessary.

There are all these cool things to research and build but you're not going to be able to afford them unless you expand wide and subjugate AI factions; i.e. there's limited opportunity to expand on neutrals without conquest. This is basically fine, but game would have retained more flavor if keeping other factions alive longer.

Tactical combat is generally hard to control, you need to be paused so much to issue orders that it's pretty similar to turn based combat regardless. If you want a modern game that is pretty similar and IMO has better tactical combat, have a look at Age of Wonders 3.

Factions are very asymmetrically balanced in the unmodded game, but this isn't necessarily a bad thing. Also, the AI probably cheats a lot but it doesn't really matter that much due to the focus being on less on pure strategy and more on the overall role playing experience. Only persistent annoyance with AI is its diplomacy which again is inadequately explained in the user interface leading to frustrating experiences.

Most of my play time with this game comes from a decade ago (before Steam release). If you can live with the low resolution graphics, I recommend it if you're a fan of Age of Wonders, Heroes of Might and Magic, and similar game series.

Ive played 3 hours of this game, so take this how you may.


now as a kid i played this, (played may be a strong word. ) 
the game barely ran whether it be from damage to the disc or just general incompatability.
The tutorials seem to tell you what to do but the game has a stiff learning curve and honestly may be the hardest strategy game i have ever played bar none.
This is mostly attributed to the fact that i have no idea what i am doing most of the time. i auto calc battles only now. because it seemed that even if i used a "superior" force my units would just fall like wheat to a scythe to enemies that by all logic shouldnt have been tough. 

Look, the game is old, i mean for a PC game its practically ancient. I get that in its Hayday it may have been a gem. but today my 22 year old brain simply cannot wrap itself around this game. i think i read somewhere that Life was the easiest to start with, and i even chose easy mode ( and sweet god if this is considered noob P***y level i dont want to see hard mode) but even still i find myself getting ruined.

the game tutorials state that the further you travel from your capital the harder the enemies, but Sh*t son i fought a level 5 hamlet that was basically my neighbor and was greeted with a Defeat screen 10 turns in ( was really 40 lol) 
You can station followers (obtained at a fixed period and their number depends on your fame. And you need your great temple first, found that out the hard way.) to different buildings in your base to generate resources. But you can only have a max of 8. meaning you can only generate 8 gold, or ale, or crystal or fame, or all 4 if you have 32 followers, per turn. upgrading your Base requires a seemingly large amount of resources as well. resources that if you choose to sit in your base and cower in fear of all the big mean baddies that want your booty like it did, will take forever to accumulate.

Again i dont understand the game. As i autocalc'd a level 2 hamlet, and recieved 38 gold and a fair sum of other resources, but did the same to a level 4 hamlet and was rewarded with practically pennies. i actually left my base, decided on a gamble and spent alot of money on cost effective swarms of units. only to find them all kick the bucket in one fight, and i recieved less than the cost of one for a reward. 
The lack of unit and item descriptions outside pictures with numbers is fairly standard for the time. sometimes it worked, sometimes you had people playing pictionary to figure out what stats they were looking at. this game, is the latter.
The artifacts too, have nothing but names ( or perhaps not. but i couldnt find the button to know) and they all have different costs at the setup before you play. I believe i heard someone say specific artifacts work better with specific factions but i dont know how you can possibly tell. hell, i dont even know what they do! 

I'm not saying its a bad game. Alot of people like it, i may be a total idiot who doesnt understand. but i do see alot of poeple who like it, enjoyed it during its prime. and i just wasnt one of them. Unless you're familiar with the game, i honestly cant recommend it without feeling like a jackass. Its Gameplay and mechanics have just aged like milk.

review:
This game was one of the original strategy RPGs that defined the genre. LOMSE got the formula right so many years ago, and so many strategy RPGs that have followed have failed to live up to my expectations due to the standard this game set. Despite the outdated graphics, this game is still very fun and has a great deal of depth. Play as Life, Order, Chaos, Water, Fire, Earth or Air as you attempt to defeat the evil Balkoth and ensure the continuation of your people. You are a lord of magic, leading your faith in this challenging game. Once you win one game, you can play as Balkoth and destroy the world if you want.

The game is filled with all manner of creative artifacts (weapons, armor, rings, amulets, scrolls, and potions) for your Lord and Champions to utilize. There are all manner of dungeons to explore. Battles take place on a tactical map, whereby you can utilize your horsemen, archers, mages, and ground units strategically to help win the battle. Battles are real time, but the primary map is turn based. Production of units is instantaneous if you have the resources, but resource production is turn based. The resources in this game are gold, ale, magic crystals, and fame. Gold is primarily used for ranged units, ale for melee units, and crystals for magic units, of which there are all manner of magic creatures to call to your aid depending on your faith.

Beyond the base game, there are also several scenario games you can play. For example, play as the wizard Merlin looking for hte next king of camelot.

If you are a fan of either RPGs or strategy games, I can say with confidence that you will love this game. That is, supposing you are not one of those that has to see sweet graphics in order to be interested. I can tell you that the graphics actually were pretty sweet at the time this game came out. I've kept coming back to this game since I first got it in the late 90s, but now I finaly have a version that works better with new operating systems. Maybe if we get lucky, they will come out with a sequel someday. 

Impressions Games no longer exists, and Sierra, who first published this game, later was bought and became a subsidary of Vivendi, from which rebellion bought the rights to Lords of Magic prior to the Vivendi buyout by activision. So the chances are slim, but who knows, maybe rebellion will take some time away from sniper elite, or the newly made Sierra (re-established in 2014 by Activision) buys back the rights and makes one? Long time fans can only hope. And as for my hope, it is only that you enjoy this awesome game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033052111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1680551514}
review:
I am writing this review to showcase my Let’s Play of this game, which I recently released on my YouTube channel named; Mangs.

Lords of Magic was the first game I ever played as a child. Gifted to me on Christmas eve when I had just turned 9 years old, it was a game that stirred my interest for turn-based strategy.  I did not even understand the language, but I loved the graphics, sounds and especially the music. I played this game so much I ended up having to re-buy it twice due to breaking two of my CD’s.

Looking back at it 20 years later, I am amazed how far this game was ahead of its time compared to other games. While it may be clunky, slow and outdated by today’s standards, it poses a real challenge to even the most hardened veteran, and it’s systems are still complex and tricky to figure out. The game’s diplomacy system, while not terribly advanced, still allows you to be somewhat tactical by befriending other nations via the use of gifts and trades. The magic is very tricky, requiring you to research your spells before using them, but once you get going, magic becomes a terribly force on the battlefield, allowing you to wipe out entire armies with your wizard alone. This would be a problem if the game was named anything else than “Lords of Magic”, but with magic being such a central theme of the game, I am okay with it being as devastating as it is.

For all the love I have for this game, it can be terribly frustrating at times though. Even your toughest  units die so incredibly fast in battle. Saving them feels like a hopeless and sometimes monotonous task, and in order to succeed you HAVE to babysit your units like crazy until they start leveling up. Even at max level however, they usually do not last very long on the battlefield, but at least they have a fighting chance.

I also heavily dislike the auto-calculate feature that allows you to resolve battles with the click of a button, as it goes way too easy on the player, often tempting you to auto-calculate simply because the result is more desirable. I suggest not using this feature at all if you want to have a good experience with this game, unless it is to quickly get rid of a small, meaningless army that would otherwise not pose a threat to you.

20 years later, this game continues to captivate and amaze me. The music, graphics and sounds are timeless to me, and completely one-of-a-kind. If you enjoyed games like Heroes of Might and Magic as a kid, you will absolutely love Lords of Magic. I seriously recommend it!

Mangs

author: {'steamid': '76561198014163253', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1484158074}
review:
[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
Lords of Magic: Special Edition is a Turn Based strategy game with RPG elements (and an RPG type game mode),  developed by Impressions Games and released Nov 19, 1997

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=839651617

[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b] The story of Lords of magic takes place in the land of Urak the whole land has been laid to ash by the sorcerer Balkoth. The rest of the explanation is left up to interpretation... You choose your class, and faction/faith and set out to save your people... or die again and again because there's so much in this game you didn't know about before, but each time you come back a little more prepared and understanding a bit more then before. [i](Did we get a bit too real? Let me explain...)[/i]

Truth be told, I don't know that I'm really qualified to speak about Lords of Magic because I didn't play it as a kid. and even now, I'll need to spend many more hours before I'm familiar enough that I might actually stand a chance while playing.
However, I did play the heck out of Lords of the Realm 2. So how different could a game made by the same developers be? ...turns out the difference could be astronomical. To me the only similarity is the music (A+ music btw, absolutely love it) and the battles.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Lets just start with the basic set up for a Lords of Magic Game [i](not a Legends of Urak, because that's basically a story of King Arthur)[/i] You first chose between three classes: Warrior, Mage, and Thief. Each class has it's own strengths weaknesses and class abilities.
Then you choose your faction or "faith". There are eight faiths; Life Death, Earth, Air, Fire, Water, Order, and Chaos. [i](you can't choose death until you beat the game by the way.)[/i] Again, each faith is specialized in a certain ways and with certain types of units.

Then you jump into the game and let the complexity begin!

It's not actually THAT bad when you're first learning how to play. As long as you just accept that things are going to end badly for you. You don't even need to battle, you can just let the computer Auto Calculate the battle for you.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=839650657

You have several different resources which are used for upgrading, hiring mercenaries, recruiting new troops, and paying your troops wages. There's Fame (You can beg for gold, in exchange for fame, or horde fame and get more people who join your cause!), Followers (followers can be put to work, or used to recruit troops), Gold, Gem's (Gem's are a bit tricky, they're used for magic, be it healing your troops in the capital city, or summoning creatures and magic users, and lastly pints of ale (Just another currently, and if I learned anything in Lords of the Realm 2, it's one of the most important! who doesn't love a good 'ol drunk  jk).

Everything is turn based, so you can move a certain distance with your army, and then end turn to receive new resources. The battles are real time though. (So very similar to Lords of the Realm mechanically speaking)

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=839652355

[b]Conclusion:[/b]  I don't know if I can articulate this very well, but at times I felt more like an "Adventuring party" which is going out exploring and hero journeying.. rather then a king protecting a country. Someone who has played longer and more might be able to articulate it better, but hopefully this review helps. Lords of Magic is a solid game, and highly recommended if you're interested in strategy games.

review:
I used to play this game all the time when I was younger. Everything about this game was gold. LOM features turn by turn gameplay, featuring 8 different faiths to choose from. It never gets old or boring. This game set the stage for future RPG and is a must play for any classic gamers. (also, it has the BEST MUSIC of any video game I have ever played)

Cons: you are not able to set screen resolution inside the game. So on my monitor, I end up with just a little window in the center of the screen that the game is in. 

The multiplayer is a pain to get working.

In the game, there are maurading parties, which are bots that come out of unconquered caves and such. If you focus on defeating the other faiths and forget the mauraders, they all begin to come out and swarm by about day 100. So you have level 12 maurading armies attacking you, which can be annoying.
